awd_titl_txt: Synmagmatic crustal thickening and the importance of garnet fractionation in making continental crust
awd_abstract_narration:
Earth has an unusual bimodal hypsometry among the rocky planets in the solar system. Today, about 70% of Earth's surface lies below ~4 km below sea level while the remaining parts of the Earth's surface ride above sea level, manifested as continents. This bimodal hypsometry drives much of the mass cycling on Earth's surface and fuels the evolution of Earth's habitability. Understanding why Earth is the only planet with such a pronounced bimodality rests on the understanding of why Earth has continents - one of the most fundamental questions of geology. In addition to these scientific impacts, this project will support a course taught on scientific illustration and field observation. Undergraduates students will be mentored, and the team will collaborate with instructors in the Houston area high schools to introduce geology and natural history to under-represented minorities, and provide short courses and lectures at Rice's continuing education program and the Houston Museum of Natural Science.

The continental crust is felsic, meaning that it is enriched in silica and depleted in Fe and Mg compared with the mafic oceanic crust. But how the continental crust achieved its felsic composition when the building blocks are mafic is unclear. In subduction zones, crustal composition correlates with crustal thickness and arcs built on thick crust tend to be more felsic, like the continental crust. This proposal seeks to understand the fundamental mechanism linking crustal thickening and differentiation, with an emphasis on the role of garnet in the formation of the continental crust. The key to testing the hypothesis is whether garnet fractionation drives oxidation or reduction of the residual magma. Thus, the objective is to quantify how much of the iron in garnet is ferric, and the researchers will study samples from the North American Cordillera and analog localities, such as New Zealand and Tibet. Ferric iron content will be determined using the electron microprobe flank method, calibrated against Mossbauer spectroscopic measurements. Trace element and oxybarometric constraints on volcanic and plutonic rocks from these areas will be conducted to evaluate whether differentiated magmas have experienced oxidation and garnet fractionation. Combined investigation of magmas and cumulates will provide a comprehensive view of continental crust-forming magmatism. The formation of continental crust is the culmination of feedbacks between climate, tectonics, magmatism, and the deep Earth.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this study was to investigate the processes by which the Earth's continental crust is formed. Specifically, we were interested in the role of deep magmatic processes on the composition of magmas when they reach the surface or erupt. We studied magmatic rocks from western North America and southern Tibet. We showed that the processes for making continental crust have their analogs in subduction zone volcanoes situated on thick continental crust. Deep in these thick crusts, magmas are forced to crystallize garnet, which removes reduced iron species and leaves behind oxidized iron species in the remaining magmas that rise to the surface. Our work shows how tectonics and magmatism are intimately linked.  This process explains why the continental crust is both depleted in total iron but oxidized. Our results have several important implications. Our results provide a framework for understanding how tectonics and magmatism work together to make continental crust through time.  Our results also have important implications for the origin of Copper porphyry deposits, an important ore for key strategic metals.  The auto-oxidation of the magma associated with garnet removal helps to make various metals available for mobilization and transport due to the oxidizing effects of destabilizing sulfide minerals. Our work on the geology of metal deposits also motivated the development of a course on strategic metals at Rice University.
